Obviously, people and equipment cannot survive long term on the surface of Venus (temperature, pressure, poisonous gases, etc.).  However, an enclosed gas-filled balloon permanently stationed at an altitude with an accommodating temperature is a distinct possibility for observation and study, and other purposes.  Probes, perhaps even manned probes, could be launched from the balloon for short term study of the surface.  By the way, I do not claim this as my original idea (though it sounds at least possibly feasible to me), I read about this strategy for colonizing Venus from another source, so smart people are at least looking into its feasibility.

Here are some Venus facts:
Like Mars and Earth, Venus are in the "Goldilocks" zone. Meaning it is in the right zone to heat the planet properly to support life.
The main theory on why it is so hot is because one side of the planet almost always faces the Sun. The mystery is why the side that faces away from the Sun is hot as well. It is theorized that a  'Green house" effect heats the other side of the planet which holds in the heat collected from the sun side of the planet. Their are many other theories such as the solid core theory on this subject.
Though one side of Venus almost always faces the Sun, it does rotate slower than it's solar year, but along with Uranus, in the opposite direction than all the other planets in our solar system.
NASA's study should be interesting. Finding out why Venus is the way it is  could lead to humans colonizing it, but I don't see humans terraforming Venus until we can figure out how to get Venus rotating in a 24 hour period.
